turn.speaker: a_l_wirin
turn.label: Mr. A. L. Wirin
turn.text: And one -- and one of my arguments is precisely because the right to discriminate it is enshrined to the constitutional right in the Constitution of California when it maybe have been because it could have been made a statute and still be the legislature couldn't touch it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't see what possible difference that makes to the federal constitutional issue that's before this Court.

turn.speaker: a_l_wirin
turn.label: Mr. A. L. Wirin
turn.text: Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether the -- whether California has acted through its legislature, through initiative of its people, through its courts, through some political subdivision, if that action violates Federal Constitution, it violates it, and if it doesn't, it doesn't.
I don't see what possible difference it makes, what instrumentality of the state that it is acting through.

turn.speaker: a_l_wirin
turn.label: Mr. A. L. Wirin
turn.text: May I just state to Your Honor why I think there may be a difference.
If the claim of a claimant is that private discriminatory action is encouraged by state action.

And hence that state action violates the Fourteenth Amendment, it seems to me it is arguable, if the state action is in the constitution, that the power of encouragement of the practice which is enshrined in the constitution, the power of encouragement is the greater if it is in the constitution rather than the statute.
Now that is all I'm arguing, and I -- I need to get back my argument.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.We appeared today as amicus in these cases because we believe that the two of them represents serious and far-reaching questions regarding the extent to which states may by indirect means substantially contribute to invidious discrimination of a kind which if practiced directly would certainly clearly violate the Fourteenth Amendment.

Now, the subject matter of the state constitutional provision involved here against the discrimination in the sales and rental of housing is an addition of subsequent concern to the executive branch of our government as is indicated by present proposals for legislation on the federal level.
These cases concerned the validity of formal legal action taken by the State of California with respect to discrimination in housing.

And in our view, the action so taken goes beyond constitutional bounds.The provision of the state constitution which I would prefer to just call “Proposition 14” because that's the way it's commonly accepted and designated throughout the State of California, is we believe demonstrably an exercise of state power in support of racial discrimination as such.
In support of this conclusion, we have urged three lines of argument.
One I proposed to deal very briefly because it's already been discussed by -- a long time.
The rest is essentially on the principle set forth in Mr. Justice Stewart's concurring opinion in the Burton case -- the Wilmington case.
And although they had believed he and Mr. Justice Frankfurter and Mr. Justice Harlan believed it was not applicable to the facts of the case they still agreed with this principle.
And that principle, as I understand it is that a state may not solemnly enact into law an explicit official authorization of racial exclusion or racial discrimination.
That is true because such an enactment by its very nature puts the state on the side of racial distinctions and racial discriminations.
Aside to which the state simply may not, under the Fourteenth Amendment tip the scales even by a hair's breadth, that's what Burton tells me.
The proposition that a state must maintain the strictest neutrality with respect to private racial discrimination has of course been firmly established and is recently in Anderson against Martin.

And in light of its history, this history of pro -- Proposition 14 which was so fully discussed in the opinion of the Supreme Court of California, and the briefs here, there can be little doubt that it actually enshrines as it carefully secured and preferred right of California citizens, a preferred right because it was deliberately put in the section with rights of free speech, free exercise of religion, et cetera.
And for that reason, we come to the second line in this argument.
And that emphasizes that Proposition 14 is not merely a state statute.
It's not a statute which is subject to the ordinary interplay of political pressures within the jurisdiction of what remains the law.
And I say in the question as to the difference between this being a constitutional provision or a statute, the important point is it can only be removed by a vote of the people of California.

And the people we are arguing about here are the underprivileged people in the State of California and I don't think anybody denied that you don't get referendum by any place without hard earned cash and plenty of it.
The whole level of political acumen in California as in any other places makes it possible that a minority group may have some political strength in an area here or an area there.
But in no state that I know of do the minority groups have statewide power.
And that's the reason it's important to recognize that this provision was deliberately put into the constitution, it was no accident.
And I agree that if it just had been a repeal, we would not be here.

The permanence it has as a constitutional provision and the sweeping effect which it must be given its all inclusive prohibition by local governmental agencies distinguishes it from a simple statute, declaring the state's neutrality.
I -- I don't understand this argument that all it does is to say, “Well, everybody's free.”

But incorporating Proposition 14 in the constitution, California said that legislation of governmental action of any sort may not be taken to eliminate or reduce private racial discrimination in housing unless one, either two-thirds of the legislature move or the issue is put up to vote by the majority of the people.
Racial and other minorities and classes which are the likely victims of discrimination in housing are virtue -- by virtue of their minority status itself, placed in an obvious disadvantage.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. General, are you saying that the effect of putting this in the constitution, the state action, putting this in the constitution as state action, and the reason why it's state action is that it has removed the subject matter from the reach of the ordinary governmental processes in the State of California, namely the legislature and the courts?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the Executive Branch.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And the Executive.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And insofar as the courts are concerned, it's an absolute bar to a legal action.

The -- as I understand Proposition 14, if someone sues on a common law theory, that he cannot be refused the rental of that building, the Court itself can dismiss it without requiring the defendant to even answer.
And the only answer the defendant would be required to make is to “Section 26” and you're out of Court.
It's an absolute bar.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you attacking the constitutionality of that constitutional provision?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The constitutionality of it?
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the Federal Constitution?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Under the Federal Constitution, I say it violates the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it didn't affect the race?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It didn't affect race.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It absolutely --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are -- are you attacking the right of California to allow its people to have a vote, one person one vote, to declare a state policy?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No sir.
It's according to what the state policy is.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If it is a state policy is to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You are not attacking -- you are not attacking the constitutionality of that as the -- within -- within the power of state to do -- to declare its policy, are you?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No sir.
I am only saying that the State of California by -- cannot by any action (Inaudible) by vote, or by legislative act, or by the courts encourage racial discrimination.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You get back --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's what I say.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You get back to the point, do you not that everybody has to in this case as to whether the Federal Constitution prevents California from doing what it's done here?
Federal Constitution --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The Fourteenth Amendment --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It does depend on the method that it's done.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No sir.
We say that -- I'm not abandoning the method.
I'm merely saying that that's a part of the picture, that's additional reason to understand what Proposition 14 means.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But you're arguing the same whether the -- under the Unruh law, prior or not?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If there was no Unruh law and no Rumford Act ever passed and Proposition 14 was the first legislation passed involved in housing, I would take the exact same position I take now, the exact same position, because the state has moved from its neutral position.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And I was asking you that question because so you seem to be impliedly attacking California's right to adopt this method of establishing its policy if it wish to do so without regard to its federal constitutionality.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh I -- I'm not attacking the method as such.
I'm just -- the result is -- I think if the Court had taken this position, would be one thing, the legislature would be one thing, the executive would be one thing.
But here, California did not say that anybody can discriminate if they want to on the grounds of race.
California, by adopting Proposition 14 and in the breadths of its language, encourages it.
It's far from being neutral.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, wouldn't you have exactly the same argument, the -- the Federal Constitutional argument if the -- if Section 26 had been enacted by the California legislature.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Been enacted?
Surely, I'd have the same argument.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Same argument.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was what I thought.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I -- I just have more force with (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't quite see why, but if you think you have, why?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I -- I -- well, I -- I -- well, let's -- let's -- let's be reasonable (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It seems to me you would have less because here, moving in the direction of letting the people of the state, the voters of the state establish their policy, the nearest to a democracy you can get.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I do not agree, Mr. Justice Black, with all due respect, that a movement in 19 -- in these years toward perpetuating racial prejudice is progress by anybody.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I wasn't talking about progress.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I was talking about movement towards democracy, to the -- get as near as you can to letting the people vote.
I'm not attacking your basic argument --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that you're making.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it does seem to me that you've gotten off on the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I do not know if I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: At that point --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When you're impliedly attacking California's method of letting its people vote to establish policies.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I think if I answer Mr. Justice Stewart's point, I might get a little --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The facts show that the argument of people in minority groups, and with help of others were able to get the Unruh Act through and were able to get the Rumford Act through.
And now that it's in the constitution that was the reason it was put in the constitution, because everybody knows that the minorities do not have that much strength on a statewide basis.
Those are facts.
I mean I'm sure you will agree with me Mr. Justice that the Real Estate Board didn't put Unruh and Rumford through, that we can be sure of.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: General, is it clear that California legislature could deprive its courts a jurisdiction in obtaining common law action?
I -- I don't know the answer to that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I'm asking you about that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't either sir.
And --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And that require a constitutional amendment?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't know the California law.

But I do know this that we have had courts, at least a court that did rule in a Civil Rights case in 1890 in Michigan, and said he did need the Civil Rights law to maintain the common law right of a Negro to be served.
That case was cited in Mr. Justice Goldberg's concurring opinion in the Maryland case.
I do say that in our brief, we set forth the large number of municipalities and local units in this country that have adopted fair housing provisions.
And they couldn't now in California if in County Z in California, all of the people decide that open housing is good and that 20 -- the 20% of the group said, “No, we don't want it.”

And the 80% say, “We want it and we are in favor of adopting a resolution in our county requiring fair housing,” they can do it under this Act and that's the point I've been trying to get through Mr. Justice Black that the vote of the small unit is gone, you can't use any local pressure.
The governor -- I mean the -- that was a mistake.
The Attorney General of the state of California has filed a brief amicus in this case.
Certainly, he doesn't agree with it.
But his hands are tied.
The whole executive branch of the government is tied.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) is a constitutional provision.
Are you against constitutional provision?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Not at all.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's -- what's the Bill of Rights or the constitutional provision to limit the local power or party unit to pass laws?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think it would be a beautiful -- I think that, really, our differences -- if this were the Unruh or the Rumford Act had been a constitutional provision, I'd be all for it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right.
(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I would say that -- I would say that the -- two, the constitutional provision has the same validity regardless of which side it takes.
But this one is a wrong one.
And it makes no difference where it is, it's wrong.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I agree with you, if it violates the Federal Constitution, it's wrong.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's what I think.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If it violates the Federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm sure it does.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Not because it's conducted in a constitutional measure, the chief measure of protecting the liberties of the people of any country.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I would be far from doing anything to interfere with the right of the people to adopt their laws and their constitution, subject only to the Fourteenth Amendment.
That's -- that's my own theory.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I wonder -- I wonder if this section might not even prevent the courts or agencies of the state from cooperating with the Federal Government in the event of an open housing statute because it says neither the state nor any subdivision or agency thereof shall deny, limit, or abridge directly or indirectly the right of any person who is willing and decides to sell and so forth.
Now, that looks to me like a pretty strong --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, we --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- an all-inclusive statement and I just wonder if they could -- under that constitutional section, if they could even cooperate with the Federal Government or the -- the Courts enforce federal rights.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I think the Courts would be obliged to because under Article VI, the judges have to take the oath to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- apply both (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I think so, but that wouldn't save the constitutionality of this Act.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Not at all.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The mere fact that they have to do it, the Supremacy Clause probably would compel them to do it but isn't this an attempt to even to go that far.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I say that this provision is an absolute bar to a court taking any action against racial discrimination in housing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And it would at least, it seems to me, be a discouragement to any -- any agency of the State of California from even cooperating with the Federal Government in any such statute.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's right.
I think in support of that is the Attorney General himself to file his brief here.
And I think that that brief would be speaking for the entire executive side of the State of California.
And the -- the real difficulty here is that we all know there is considerable movement toward voluntarily working out open housing problems.
And the movement is much accentuated on the local level.
I don't know whether it's true in California or not, but I am talking about the reports that we filed in our brief.
All of those, I mean, we right here, we know up in Montgomery County.
There's a big movement there.
It's all over the country.
But here, you can't do it.
The other point is that even if somebody -- the people that reads this and there despite the fact that it's not directly material, the literature in all of it was set up.
It's in the UAW's brief and all.
There's some people that now whose conscience is telling them they should open their houses up.
They should open their apartments up.
They get the idea that the State says “Don't do it!”
It gives the -- the person whose conscience is working on him a block that says, “You don't have to do this.”
And it's the opposite of the neutral position that the State should take in these matters.
And I say the neutral position because I don't want it understood that I would object to the State taking the other position like the -- the Rumford Act or what have you.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You said they can have that law but they can't repeal it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No sir, they can repeal.
They could have repealed Rumford.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But that's drawing a distinction between what was done by the State and what they actually did.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, my point is, if they -- they repealed Unruh and Rumford, the courts could -- could move in if they were (Inaudible), and say that the common law is not what you say it is.
The local county units could move in.
Maybe the -- I don't know the powers of the Governor but I mean maybe some executive branch could move in.
There are lot of ways that this problem with racial discrimination in housing could be solved, if -- even if Unruh and Rumford were repealed.
But instead of just repealing them, they'd put in this positive provision the bars anybody, bars anybody from interfering.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Perhaps through a constitutional method (Inaudible), isn't it?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's perfectly legitimate -- we don't quarrel that it was not properly adopted.
But when it was adopted, it was about to its subject to this Court's determination as to whether it was constitutional or not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Subject to the Federal Constitution of course.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And subject to its own State Court.
And I'm not abandoning the fact that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- that its own State Supreme Courts said it was.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean the State Supreme Court can do away with this constitution?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It -- it can declare a provision.
The Supreme Court deliberately said that we don't use that right.
But we moved purely on federal grounds.
I think that's the reason the Court did it.
It was because they were worried about that point.
I think it's what it was.
But the -- the ultimate decision would have to be made by this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If I -- if I understand your argument correctly, and you tell me if I'm mistaken, it would be substantially the same argument even if there had been -- never been a Rumford or an Unruh Act, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That no state could do this --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- regardless of its prior legislative enactments.

And if this -- that the enactment of this constitutional provision in and of itself quite apart for many previous history of what the state had or had not enacted in this area would violate the Fourteenth Amendment --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I would say --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I would say that that is our position.
And the reason is that the state has shifted from its neutral position on race.
And when you shift from your neutral position, the thumb is on the scales.
And I used that the line of cases of -- ending up with burden.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I -- I thought that your argument would be substantially the same argument if the -- if there had never been any statutes weren't passed in this area by a state and if the common law had been the way -- the conventional common law has been with the exception of your (Inaudible) case and a couple others.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So that the common law generally had been (Inaudible) that it would still -- that the affirmative adoption by a state of Section 26 would nonetheless violate the Fourteenth Amendment (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I believe I was correct in understanding if that is your basic argument --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- point apart from any -- the prior history of any Rumford Act or Unruh Act or anything else.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We just say that that helps our basic position.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, but I --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We don't need it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But I think on analysis and you tell me if I'm wrong, your basic position is that whether this 26 had been adopted by California with its particular history or by North Dakota, or by Ohio, or by Mississippi, or by any other state it would be violative of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I would say so because it's giving encouragement to racial discrimination and it is shackling handcuffing all state agencies from doing anything to eliminate it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what I understood.
And I -- I want you to -- these are not rhetorical questions.
I'm asking for information so I'd --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I know that sir.
(Inaudible) thank you sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well Mr. Solicitor General, these suits were brought in Orange County, weren't they?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: One was in Orange County and one was in Los Angeles.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: All right, let's take the Orange County.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let us suppose that the California legislature after this suit was instituted, passed a statute saying that the courts of Orange Country shall not entertain any lawsuits or where there was a claim of -- for relief based upon the refusal of a property owner to sell or rent housing to the plaintiff, would that be in conflict with Federal Constitution?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think so.
I think there's no question about it.
It's also this case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that would be in con -- well, I would say -- I was kind of thinking about this case.
[Laughter] Was that -- would that be a conflict with the Fourteenth Amendment?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think definitely yes.
This case was filed before 14, and it laid around when 14 came out, the defendant came in it says, 14 dismissed, it's dismissed.
That's what happened.
Oh, I'm not saying it was passed discretionary for this person but with all due respect it did.
It's our position that in both of these cases, the situation as it exists cannot be put within the four corners of the Fourteenth Amendment for the three reasons set out.
The one we urged the strongest is the overbreadth and the extent to which it was done, the encouragement point is a secondary point to our argument.

But on any basis, we believe that the judgment of the Supreme Court of California should be affirmed and back to the question we asked yesterday, we don't necessarily urge that beyond the exact same grounds as the Supreme Court of California but we think our three points do stand up and require the affirmance.

section.heading: Argument of Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Pruitt.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

First in response to several questions from the Court, it seems to be clear that the risk of being presumptuous that is the duty of this Court to read this measure in a way to say that's validity not in a -- with unfriendly way in an effort to read in -- into it some provision that is not reasonably implied.

For example, I think there is nothing in this measure that can reasonably be read that says that the State Courts in California are prohibited by this measure from performing their Constitutional duty to enforce Federal Rights, whether they arise under a federal statute or under the Federal Constitution.

Nor indeed as evidenced by the exercise of jurisdiction by the State Courts in these cases, does it deprive the State Courts of the obligation to entertain claims which might involve the rule of law set forth in Section 26 to interpret that rule of law and to apply it to the effects of the case before it.
And I think it's quite ironic.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: How -- how can you read that exception under the statute?
Is there any language in here or -- because the language seems to be about as broad as it can be phrased.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Justice Fortas, the language I think establishes a rule of law in California.
Rules of law are applied by courts all the time.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, this -- this one is (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Restatement -- pardon me, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: This is a constitutional provision.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And it says that, “Neither the State nor any subdivision or agency.”
And would you construe that to mean to -- not to apply to the courts?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: It's binding -- it's binding on the courts in the sense that the courts ought to apply the rule law that's provided for on this measure.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But it is -- and your argument then compared to what has been said by the counsel that this -- that the phrase, “Neither the State nor any subdivision or agency” does not include courts in the exercise of their own jurisdiction as we say is from enforcing State action.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: It prohibits the -- it tries to prohibit the court from applying a rule of law different than the one recited in the provision, that's true, but that's true of any statute held the Court that under particular circumstances this is what the law is.
And a court is obligated to apply that rule of law unless it violates some constitutional provisions.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I -- I think you -- as I had understood your argument, Mr. Pruitt, it was that nothing in here and obviously nothing in here does and quite obviously nothing in here could take away from the courts their duty to apply the Federal Constitution.
I think that is (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- between you and my Brother Fortas which -- that you were talking about, the Federal Constitution and he -- he thought you're talking about the State Constitution.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Obviously there's a change in this -- in this (Inaudible) -- this is an addition to the State Constitution and insofar as its provisions, do not violate the Federal Constitution the State Courts are bound by it.
But you're quite right insofar as this does violate the Federal Constitution under the Supremacy Clause, the State judges have the duty of following the Federal Constitution (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly, and that's what -- that's what the court below attempted to deal in this case we think erroneously but it certainly attempted to do what it thought it would require to do by the Federal Government.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And to the extent that the Supremacy Clause is not involved.
This Constitutional Provision does remove in the California court common law jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I would disagree, Mr. Justice Fortas.
It tells them what the rule of law is, that the facts that -- that rule of law (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I think -- (Inaudible) -- that is a meaningful distinction and maybe I'll contend that it's not.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I might also say Mr. Justice Fortas that with respect to this method being an -- a departure from the ordinary processes of government in California or to placing this measure in the California Constitution has a significance that would be similar to an amendment to Federal Constitution, for example, just isn't so.
This is a normal procedure in California.
Our Constitution has been amended about 300 times since 1879 by initiative and other procedures.
I don't say it isn't necessarily good but on the other hand, it isn't necessarily bad either.

Now, it's quite ironic, I think that the respondents in this case supported by the United States and the Attorney General of California say, “They would be perfectly valid for the people of California to repeal the entire Unruh Act, the entire Rumford Act,” presumably to repeal all of our antidiscrimination laws which I think it's been conceded the State had no obligation to enact in the first place.

Here, where the people are trying to affect a very limited repeal of only one tiny portion of conduct and place it within the discretion and live it to the conscience of the individuals, that they say violates Federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I noticed you don't cite in your brief Truax versus Corrigan.
Have you considered that?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I have considered it and I believe I did cite the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I don't find it in your index.
But don't bother now, but --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I'll say that I've --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How do you distinguish Taft's opinion in Truax v. Corrigan from this case, where the State of Arizona had withheld a remedy for a denial by private people of equal protection, equal treatment?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I would prefer to rely on the dissenting opinion in that case, You Honor, which I think reflects to the current.
And I'm proud to rely on it, I might say because --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But you see, the dissenting opinion, it doesn't help you.
There were three of them and I just refreshed my recollection on them.
They don't help you much because they went off on the grounds if there was no lack of equal protection.
And here we have -- any line drawn between race is a suspect line in this country.
That's true isn't it, by the reason of the 13th, 14th, and 15th (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, certainly, yes.
I -- I believe --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I don't think the dissenting opinion address themselves to State action.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I believe they address themselves to this point and I believe that the current opinions of this Court fully support the dissenting opinion of Mr. Justice Brandeis and Mr. Justice Holmes --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I don't think (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: -- that the legislative power includes the right of the State to decide what its law is going to be in an area where Constitutional Rights are not affected.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That's on the grounds of what is -- with classifications, yes, making a classification.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.
But in that case the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) we don't have that problem here but we do have problem as to whether or not the State can turn over its -- the municipal function of zoning to a real estate (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I regret that, Your Honor thinks that that's what this measure means because I don't think that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's a --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: -- it's a fair reading of it, if I may say so.

And further, as I understand the holding and Truax v. Corrigan, it was that the Federal Constitution prohibited Arizona from adopting a law that would bar the remedy of injunctions and labor disputes.

This is back in 1924 and if -- if that's presently the constitutional law of the decisions in this Court it would surprise me because the Norris–La Guardia Act in the Federal level does just that and no one, I think --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But that's been (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: -- has challenged --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, that's been removed by Congressional power.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That -- that is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The constitutional theory of Taft is -- is something that I don't your brief has addressed itself to.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: No, as I say the reason I didn't cite the majority opinion is because of my opinion it's not currently of the law.

Now with respect to whether the California court made any factual determination of encouragement, Mr. Wirin read a portion of a sentence from the opinion but he left out the phrase which I think establishes that really the California Supreme Court was making a statement of a legal conclusion.

There is the Statement Mr. Wirin read, “Here, the State has affirmatively acted to change its existing law from a situation where in a discrimination practice was legally restricted to one where in it is encouraged,” and this is the part that was omitted, “within the meaning of the cited decisions.”

But I think that's clearly a legal conclusion as to what this Court meant by encouragement in such decisions as Burton v. Wilmington Parking Authority, the Robinson v. Florida, and another cases cited in the opinion.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Pruitt, is this an argument that this -- 26 can be read as nothing more than a mere repealer of the provisions of Rumford and Unruh?
Is that your basic position, isn't it?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That -- it is a --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If I understand your -- everyone who has argued on the other side instead of, that's all it means, it wouldn't even be here.
They've been --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct and that's all it means with this exception, Mr. Justice Brennan.
And that is it's in our constitution that it reserves to the people the power to enact the statute in the future.
Now if that aspect of it is valid and we think it clearly is then it is nothing more than a repealer.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, how -- I still come back to what I asked then.
You -- you certainly don't agree and let the Supreme Court of California interpret the Section 26 to do, do you?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: My analysis indicates that its interpretation was that the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: -- nullification of this statute --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the other side doesn't agree with you.
You -- you're not in agreement as to what the -- on the interpretations that the California Supreme Court gave to 26.
You say it's only a mere repealer.
And they say if that's all it is, they wouldn't be here.
They say it's much more than that.
You say it's not any more than that, is that right?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
The only thing --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And -- what are we suppose to do in that -- in that circumstance?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I assume the Court will have to decide whether I'm right or they're right as to what the California Supreme Court held.
And I think, an analysis of that decision --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) the California Supreme Court didn't really tell us, isn't it?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Well I think they did, Your Honor.
If you read their decision in the light of Hill v. Miller where they say in California there is no right of action under these circumstances unless there's a statute.
Even though in that case the landlord was very obliging in putting his notice termination that he was relying specifically on the right given to him by Section 26 to terminate for this tenancy.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Pruitt, isn't it consistent with what -- would it be consistent with what the Supreme Court of California said -- to say that whether or not this is a mere repealer that Proposition 14 encourages discrimination within the meaning of the cited cases.
They didn't focus on whether or not it is mere repealer or it isn't -- or they didn't -- that they didn't really put it in those words, did they?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: No.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But they said whatever it is, we think it encourages discrimination.
That's about as far as they went.Was it (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- many of the cited case?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: They described what happened as the sequence of legislative activity and they say this change of policy constitutes encouragement of racial discrimination.
They said that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you -- I think I asked you the other day, I'm not sure yesterday, if the -- if Proposition 14 had said that Rumford and Unruh are hereby repealed and private parties are authorized to discriminate.
Would you -- what would you say about that?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I think the singling out of discrimination in any official statute might raise a serious constitutional problem, just as Your Honor thought there was a serious problem in the Georgia statute in Evans v. Newton because it singled out in Your Honor's opinion, racial discrimination as permissible conduct brought at the same time living in doubt whether you can discriminate on any other grounds but race.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: For example, I didn't single out racial discrimination.
I just said that people are authorized to discriminate in the selling of their house.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That would be perfectly valid.
I -- I misunderstood your question.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And do you think you have to take that position?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think if it -- do you think if -- if that statute -- if that kind of a proposition was invalid, you could still win here.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Because I think the constitutional issue here --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Don't you think that this is an authorization to discriminate, Proposition 14?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: It's an authorization to act without the compulsion of government.
Now, that's an authorization to discriminate, that maybe a way of putting it but it's not an encouragement to discriminate.

It's an encouragement to act on accordance with the dictates of your conscience, which is true of all areas of conduct which the government either commands, not be -- neither commands to be done nor prohibits from being done.
This broad middle ground where the government does nothing so to speak, neither prohibits it nor does it command it.
In those areas, freedom means that people are supposed to act in accordance with their consciences and it is to be hoped that they don't discriminate.
But it includes, that's one of curse of freedom is that some people will.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So authorization as such is not necessarily invalid as argued.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That -- that is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't -- I don't think you have to say that and I think it's perfectly legitimate, some acts where a state authorizes something to be done to say that it's made it legal.
But it's not, and it says we're not going to have any law on this subject.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That's what --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's quite different.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That's what this measure says.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And what's -- what's done is here is a play on the words encourage and discourage.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But we have -- we have this situation and I wonder if you've found any -- any analogies to it in other constitutions that have been sustained, well recognized of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments were -- were designed to prevent discrimination of the Negro.
Now, do you know of any other analogies where -- where the courts have sustained a statute or a constitutional provision that is designed to circumvent that right?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Well in the form of Your Honor's question, I don't believe there would be such a case of a statute --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well -- well (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: -- that was designed to circumvent the right not to be discriminated?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Circumvent the purpose of the Fourteenth Amendment.
The purpose of the Fourteenth Amendment is to prevent discrimination against Negroes.
It is true that it only operates against the State not just against the individuals.

But do you know of any other constitutional provision or statute which is to stand by this Court or higher courts, where the purpose was -- where the statute itself said that the people, affirmatively, that the people should not be interfered with in their right of discrimination.
And isn't that what we have here?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I know -- I know of such case that holds it on this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about the Civil Right cases?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: But then I was going to say Mr. Justice Black that the whole -- the whole line of authorities from the Civil Rights cases down to the Guest Case last term, in making the distinction between State and private actions seems to make crystal clear that a state has an absolute right consistent with the Fourteenth Amendment to say this is the kind of conduct we can prevent if we think it's necessary or desirable.
We don't have to do it in the Federal Constitution.
And if we decide not to take a position on this kind of field -- in this field, there's nothing in the Federal Constitution that says we cannot.
Now let's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I -- I don't -- I don't disagree with you on the fact that they can -- can do nothing about it?But can they encourage -- encourage it by a provision of this kind?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I think the central, the core question in this case, Chief Justice please, is whether this rule of law is consistent with the Fourteenth Amendment.
Now in 1959, everybody says that California just had the Common Law Rule and it wasn't printed in the statute so it wasn't in the constitution.
There would be no Federal Constitutional question if the Court rendered judgment for the property owners in this case.
Now in 1967, all of sudden that same rule of law raises a serious constitutional question.
Now, why is that so?

Why should it make a difference that California has experimented in this field by adopting a statute to see whether or not it would assist in the situation, the people say we don't want the statute and they repealed it.
Why should that conduct of the legislative groups in California make it any different constitutional question than it would have been in 1959?
Or for that matter, any difference in the constitutional question should these cases come up from Illinois or Texas or Mississippi?
Why should there be a different rule of Constitutional Law applicable to California?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't think there is but couldn't they -- couldn't they simply have repealed the Rumford and the Unruh Amendments here and let it go with that and then the State would be neutral?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: As I said at the beginning, Mr. Chief Justice, it seems to me it's very ironic to suggest that a repeal of these measures, which is a much more drastic step, from the step that people took here.
They didn't repeal the Unruh Act.
It prohibits discrimination on racial or religious grounds in business establishments of every kind whatsoever.
My opponents here say that California can repeal that whole law, consistent with the Federal Constitution.
But what they can't do is the (Inaudible) of that law, this narrow area of conduct for a private property on.
I find that very ironic and unacceptable under the Federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I think it's a legislative process for -- for the legislature to pass and repeal laws.
That's what the legislature is there for.
But does that follow?
The State has the right to say that it no longer can pass a law that is in furtherance of the Fourteenth Amendment so far as discrimination is concerned.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Again, that's not what this measure says.
It says it can pass such a law when the people pass it in that part of the process of the Democratic Government in California.
I know nothing in the Federal Constitution that says that kind of a democratic process is prohibited.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in any event Proposition 14 ends up like creating a constitutional right to discriminate?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: I disagree with the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I mean --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: It doesn't create any right of any kind, Your Honor.
It recognizes a rule of law which was created many years ago by -- and it's reported in Black Stones Commentary and approved by this Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) -- yes, but let's just say that before Rumford and Unruh, was there a constitutional right to discriminate in California?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Constitutional right in the sense of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There was not because --

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- Unruh and -- Unruh and Rumford did away with the right to discriminate.

But now, there is a Constitutional Right to discriminate in the State of California in the sense that no legislature -- no legislative act or ordinance is valid in that State, but isn't a Constitutional right, it's nothing, is it?
People have the constitutional right to discriminate much have the (Inaudible) the right to free to speech.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: They have a State Constitutional Right in the sense that they may -- they act in that manner until and unless a valid statute prohibits them from doing so.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They have the say when they have -- by the due process (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That they have a right to be free, conduct themselves as they please so long as they do not violate some law enacted to prevent or -- or aid something.
(Inaudible) not to have a life, liberty, or property taken away without due process except by due process of law which means the law of the land.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: That is certainly my understanding, Mr Justice Black, and I think it was stated by this Court long ago as Buchanan v. Warley in about 1917 insofar as I know has not been changed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you have the initiative in California or legislative acts?

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, the initiative applied both to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_o_pruitt_jr
turn.label: Mr. Samuel O. Pruitt, Jr.
turn.text: -- Constitutional Amendments and the legislative acts, but either one is modifiable in the future only by further action of the people.
For the fact that this is in the California Constitution by initiative as distinguished from the California statute by initiative has no bearing on who has the right repeal it.

Effect in short, if the Court pleased that the court below exercised the judicial power of the United States to strike down a rule of law which the people of California adopted in the orderly manner of democracy which we practice there.
We asked the Court not to exercise that power to overrule the judgment of the people here.
The people are the only sorts for the ultimate and abiding solution of the kind of problem that's been raised by my opposition.

And if these arguments that they are addressing to this Court or addressed to the legislative bodies in California for the people, they are the ones that have to be convinced that their method of approach to this problem is preferable to the one adopted by the people.
We ask that the judgments be reversed.
